article-meta.aff: 1School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Faculty of Science, The University of Western Australia, Perth, WA, Australia

author-notes.corresp: Dr Foteini Hassiotou, Hartmann Human Lactation Research Group, School of Chemistry and Biochemistry (M310), Faculty of Science, The University of Western Australia, 35 Stirling Highway, Crawley, Perth, WA 6009, Australia Email: foteini.hassiotou@uwa.edu.au

abstract.p: Reflecting millions of years of adaptation and optimization, milk is unique to the species that produces it and for the young of which it is intended, with large variations in both lactation strategies and milk composition existing among different mammalian species. Despite this, milk has the consistent function of providing nourishment, protection, and developmental programming to the young, with short- and long-term effects. Among its components that confer these functions, breast milk contains maternal cells, from leukocytes to epithelial cells of various developmental stages that include stem cells, progenitor cells, lactocytes, and myoepithelial cells. Although in the first 150 years since their discovery, breast milk cells were mostly studied for their morphological traits, technological advances in the last decade have allowed characterization of breast milk cell types at the protein and messenger RNA levels. This is now paving the way for investigation of the functions of these cells in the breastfed infant and the use of breast milk as a tool to understand the normal biology of the breast and its pathologies. This review summarizes the current knowledge of breast milk cellular heterogeneity and discusses future prospects and potential applications.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Milk is produced in the mammary glands of mammals for the protection as well as nutritional and developmental support of their neonates.1,2 Milk is a complex fluid containing lipids, proteins, carbohydrates, and molecules with bioactivity, such as vitamins, immunomodulatory factors, and mediators of developmental effects/programming.2-5 Despite the consistency in the general composition and role of milk among mammalian species, differences exist in the specific milk composition between species.1 These differences largely reflect the species’ evolutionary histories, for example, the specific needs and growth rate of the young of different mammals.1,2 In addition to its biochemical composition, milk contains maternal cells that are live in fresh milk, suggesting that they may have specific functions in the milk-fed young.

Milk varies not only between but also within species.1 In women, this is influenced by the stage of lactation, milk removal during breastfeeding or milk expression, and maternal diet.3,6-11 These variations are buffered by mobilization of maternal somatic nutrient stores and the changing infant needs to result in personalized breast milk that reflects the balance between maternal diet, metabolism, transport, and secretion.9 The intra-individual variation in milk composition adds further complexity to the understanding of the function of the different components of human milk during lactation. Certainly, one of the most understudied milk components has been the maternal cells,2 and therefore, their properties and inter-/intra-individual variations are poorly understood. Recent technological advancements of single cell analysis have allowed characterization of the cellular composition of breast milk in women. This review will summarize the current knowledge of the cellular types, hierarchy, and properties of human milk, discussing the recent discovery of pluripotent stem cells in human milk and potential implications for future research.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: PubMed was searched for articles examining human breast milk cells. We considered all articles written in English and presented a synthesis of the results. In cases where similar information was produced by multiple studies, the most comprehensive and/or recent articles were discussed. Where no studies were available on human breast milk cells, the animal studies that were most representative of the area of investigation were cited.

sec.title: The Mammary Cellular Hierarchy
sec.p: A cellular hierarchy is present in the breast, manifested at its completeness during lactation.2 Two types of luminal epithelial cells exist in the lactating mammary gland: the epithelial cells that line the lumen of alveoli, some of which differentiate into lactocytes, and the ductal epithelial cells that line the lumen of the ducts. Lactocytes can be identified by expression of milk proteins (β-casein, α-lactalbumin, lactoferrin), cytokeratin 18 (CK18), and the presence of fat globules.12 Ductal epithelial cells typically do not produce milk proteins and express cytokeratin 19 (CK19).2 In contrast to luminal cells, myoepithelial cells lining the ducts and alveoli express cytokeratin 14 (CK14) and smooth muscle actin (SMA). It is thought that both luminal and myoepithelial cells originate from a single cell precursor (common progenitor), which in turn originates from mammary stem cells (MaSCs) and further differentiates into more restricted progenitors for the 2 epithelial types.13,14 However, the identity and properties of intermediate steps along this hierarchy are still poorly understood, which is particularly so for the human breast in its fully mature state, that is, during lactation. Current understanding is that the profile CD49fhigh/CD29+/CD24low characterizes bipotent MaSCs in the resting (from non-pregnant, non-lactating females) human breast and that subsequent progenitors gradually lose expression of the stem cell marker CD49f.13,15,16 MaSCs are also thought to express cytokeratin 5 (CK5), which seems to be highly specific to the myoepithelial layer.2 It has recently become apparent that the cellular hierarchy of the lactating breast is represented in breast milk, which will provide a powerful tool, due to its non-invasive and plentiful nature, to advance knowledge in the field.

sec.title: Breast Milk Cells: The Early Work
sec.p: Cells were first observed in human milk by the microscopist Anthony van Leewenhoek (1632-1723), although at the time their cellular nature had not been established.17 A century later, Donné (1838) and Henle (1841) performed microscopic examinations of colostrum. Both scientists noted the presence of cells in colostrum, then named “granular bodies”18 or “colostrum bodies.”19 In 1868, Beigel clearly described these bodies as cells.20 Since then, a number of reports have been made available on the origin of these cells, which were considered to be mesenchymal,21 immune,22,23 or epithelial.24,25 Others more appropriately considered the colostrum cells as a mixed population of epithelium- and mesenchyme-derived cells.26,27 The majority of these early investigators considered the colostrum/milk cells to be exfoliated from the mammary gland. Later investigations, however, suggest that, at least for some of these cells, the main source is the maternal circulation.

It was not until Smith and Goldman28 100 years later that more sophisticated methods were used to study colostrum cells, assigning a significant portion of them to the leukocyte lineage. Slightly earlier, Holmquist and Papanicolaou analyzed smears of mammary secretions from lactating and non-lactating women as a non-invasive method for the diagnosis and study of breast malignancy,29,30 given that breast biopsies from pregnant or lactating women are very seldom warranted and thus very difficult to obtain. In addition, others began using breast milk cell smears to study the normal biology of the lactating breast. Since then, most studies have been largely descriptive, with very little information about potential changes in breast milk cellular composition with the stage of lactation.26 These early studies and, in particular, Holmquist and Papanicolaou’s29 account of breast milk cell content suggested the following cell types to be characteristic of human milk:

list-item.p: Foam cells (or “cells of Donné”). These cells were considered to be leukocytes by some investigators, whereas others regarded them as epithelial cells. Indeed, “foam cells” displayed traits that are shared between leukocytic and epithelial (milk-secretory) subpopulations, such as the presence of lipid droplets (and thus staining with Sudan IV and Oil Red O), a large nucleus or multinucleation, and cytoplasmic vacuolation. Given that the identity of “foam cells” is debatable, this term is no longer used to avoid confusion.
Leukocytes. These cells often formed aggregates, existing also as single cells. They were considered to be the most abundant blood-related cell element in milk smears.

Epithelial cells. Although single epithelial cells had been reported previously in breast milk, Holmquist and Papanicolaou29 were the first to describe in detail epithelial cell clusters of various sizes in mammary secretions during pregnancy and the first week postpartum. They classified them into 5 different subtypes based on cellular morphology, albeit highlighting the presence of transitional/intermediate forms. Interestingly, they assigned each cluster type to a different epithelial differentiation stage, providing the first observation of a cellular hierarchy in breast milk, involving undifferentiated cells; 50 years later, Cregan et al31 provided the first evidence supporting the presence of stem cells in breast milk.

sec.p: In subsequent years, human milk cell research focused on colostrum or early lactation breast milk and its leukocyte content. The non-immune breast milk cell types have been given minimal attention despite being the dominant cell population of mature human milk,32 which is what the infant receives for the majority of the breastfeeding period. In the last decade, exciting advances are revealing the presence of a cellular hierarchy in breast milk, including stem cells.2,31,33-35

sec.title: Heterogeneity of Breast Milk Cellular Content
sec.p: Large differences exist in reports of the cellular content of human milk between studies but also between women of a single study. Factors associated with these variations include breast fullness, the stage of lactation, the health status of the mother/infant dyad, the permeability of the basement membrane, and the development of the breast epithelium. At the same time, methodological consistency between studies and adoption of accurate and reliable techniques for assessment of milk cell content may provide a better picture of these variants and may reduce the apparent variability.

Based on current data, the cell content of human milk of any lactation stage ranges approximately between 10 000 and 13 000 000 cells/mL, reflecting a wide spectrum of inter-individual variation2,12,36-42 (Figure 1A). Colostrum and early lactation milk appear to often contain more cells than mature breast milk,12,36,37,43 although this may at least in part relate to the lower volume of available colostrum compared to mature breast milk, suggesting that the relative difference may functionally be a dilution factor. Short-term intra-individual variations in breast milk cell content associated with breastfeeding/milk removal have also recently been reported, showing a relationship with breast fullness and breast milk fat content.36 Although the mechanisms for this association need to be explored further, it is clear that breast milk cell content is dynamic, changing in both the short- and long-term in response to individual variants, such as breastfeeding patterns and the stage of lactation.2

caption.p: Breast Milk Cell Content across Lactation and Effects of Breastfeeding on Breast Milk Cell Composition

A. Range in breast milk cell content (10 000-13 500 000 cells/mL milk) across different stages of lactation in a cohort of n = 234 women. Cells were counted using a hemocytometer. Cell viability was measured using Trypan Blue exclusion and ranged from 70% to 100%, with the majority of samples having cell viabilities greater than 90% (n = 202). B. Changes in expression of stem cell marker STRO-1 by breast milk cells around a feed. Sampling levels (5 mL each) included a prefeed sample, a sample collected immediately postfeeding, and then consecutive samples collected every 30 minutes for the next 3 hours. The baby removed 140 mL of breast milk during that feed and fed from only 1 breast (the sampled breast). Expression of STRO-1 in each sample was quantified by Flow Activated Cell Sorting (FACS) via isolation and washing of breast milk cells and staining with an anti-STRO-1 antibody (from Hassiotou et al35). Measurements were done in a FACS Calibur Flow Cytometer and analysis in Flowjo. The graph shows the standardized difference in Mean Fluorescence Intensity (MFI) between the test and the control.

sec.p: Variability has been reported not only in breast milk cell content but also in cell composition, both between and within women. For example, we have recently demonstrated a changing cellular composition in response to breastfeeding/milk removal within a woman36 (Figure 1B). At the same time, colostrum leukocyte content varies between women, with a wide range reported from 13.2% up to 70.4% leukocytes of total cells.37 Within a dyad and at any lactation stage, infection of the mother and/or the infant is associated with an increase in the milk leukocytic population that decreases with resolution of the infection.37 Thus, it is well established that human milk comprises a heterogeneous cell population (Figure 2A), with the dominant cell types often being of leukocytic origin in colostrum and early lactation milk, and of epithelial origin in mature breast milk in healthy mother/infant dyads.2,12,32,37,39

caption.p: Cells in Breast Milk, Their Origin from the Breast Epithelium, and Their Potential to Synthesize Milk

A. Freshly isolated human milk cells. B. CD14 (green) staining in alveoli of the human lactating breast. Blue: nuclear stain (DAPI). Scale bar: 10 µm. C. Functional mammospheres producing β-casein generated by the culture of breast milk stem cells (adapted from Hassiotou et al35). Scale bar: 10 µm.

sec.title: Leukocytes
sec.p: Infants are born with an immature immune system and are thus susceptible to various infections.44 Breastfeeding arguably provides the most effective protection for the infant as its immune system develops,45-49 including an extensive array of molecules with immunoprotective functions. These include sIgA, fatty acids, lactoferrin, α-lactalbumin, lysozyme, oligosaccharides, cytokines, and antioxidants, to name a few. In fact, the human milk proteome has been recently extended to 976 proteins, many of which are known to possess immune properties.50,51 In addition to immune molecules, breast milk contains blood-derived leukocytes that are believed to be transported into the milk via the paracellular pathway.2 Often, cellular and biochemical milk components work synergistically to have a direct or indirect effect (eg, modifying the microenvironment of the infant gut) to increase infant immunity.

The leukocyte is the most studied cell type in human milk. Leukocytes may constitute a considerable portion of the total milk cells, depending on the stage of lactation and the health status of the breastfeeding dyad.32,37-39 Breast milk leukocytes include granulocytes and mononuclear leukocytes, such as lymphocytes, monocytes, and macrophages.28,37,52-55 In human colostrum, macrophages are the predominant leukocyte type (40%-50% of total leukocytes) followed by polymorphonuclear neutrophils (40%-50% of total leukocytes) and lymphocytes (5%-10% of total leukocytes).12,54,56 Of the lymphocytic populations, T cells constitute the majority (approximately 83%) as opposed to B cells (4%-6%).54,55 Many of these leukocytes are activated, motile, and interactive.28,52 This suggests that they confer active immunity to the infant.55 This was further supported by in vivo studies in animal models showing active milk leukocyte transfer through the intestinal epithelium into the blood circulation of the young, and movement to and engraftment in different organs, including the mesenteric nodes, liver, and spleen.57-61 In addition to a function in the young, breast milk leukocytes are thought to protect the mammary gland from infection during lactation.62

Emerging evidence suggests that breast milk cellular content is influenced by the health status of both the mother and infant,63 and this might contribute to the wide range of leukocyte counts reported in the literature. Recent investigations into whether immunologic factors in breast milk change as a result of infant infection found that breast milk leukocyte and macrophage content increased during infections and decreased significantly upon recovery.37,64 While it is possible that infants with either respiratory or gastrointestinal infection may infect their mother such that she mounts an immune response and subsequently leukocytes and other immune molecules are transferred into her breast and enter breast milk, logically this is less likely for infants with localized or bacterial infections. Similar results were found in an earlier study where the breast milk of mothers of infants hospitalized with bronchiolitis showed greater numbers of viable cells, and the cells displayed skewed cytokine response to live respiratory syncytial virus, which is the major organism responsible for bronchiolitis, compared to a non-specific mitogen concanavalin A.63 These data provide further evidence of activation of immunomodulatory components of breast milk in response to infant infection. The local stimulation of the breast by the infant’s pathogens is likely to happen during breastfeeding via the retrograde ductal flow at the second half of milk ejection, and merits further investigation.37 Expanding on this, we have recently shown that although colostrum contains considerable numbers of leukocytes (13%-70%), leukocytes in mature human milk are few (0%-2%), increasing in response to general or organ-specific infections of the breastfeeding mother and/or infant and returning to baseline levels upon recovery.37 Further investigation in this area is warranted, with breast milk cells having the potential to be used as diagnostic markers for both breast and infant health.

It must be noted that reported ranges of leukocyte content for colostrum and breast milk are likely to be overestimated and the epithelial content underestimated in cases when basic microscopic examinations are employed. Engel25 first highlighted in 1953 that similarities exist between certain leukocytic and epithelial milk subpopulations, as discussed above, pointing out that misclassification of some cells may occur. Therefore, it is advisable to employ more advanced techniques for examinations of milk leukocytic content, such as flow cytometry using monoclonal antibodies against markers that are specific to leukocytes. In this case, care must be taken to consider a panel of markers that appropriately exclude breast epithelial populations. For example, the marker CD14, despite being a leukocyte marker, is also expressed by epithelial cells65,66 (Figure 2B) and thus should be used in conjunction with leukocyte-specific markers, such as CD45.

sec.title: Epithelial Cells
sec.p: Epithelial cells (both ductal and alveolar, luminal-epithelial and myoepithelial) are responsible for both the structure and function of the lactating breast and compose up to 99% of the cellular component of breast milk2,37,67 in healthy dyads. This is in contrast to cow’s milk, in which the predominant cell type across all stages of lactation is the macrophage.12,32,68 This may be due to a number of factors, including the regular udder milking rather than suckling that occurs in dairy cows, the udders of which are stimulated to produce milk at their physiological capacity; the dairy environment; and/or a different evolutionary physiology, mammary anatomy, and milk flow compared to women.

Breast milk epithelial cells were originally hypothesized to occur as a consequence of apoptosis. However, recent evidence shows that the majority of these cells are viable in freshly expressed breast milk37 and can be propagated in primary culture to form functioning mammospheres35,69 (Figure 2C). This leads to an alternate theory that epithelial cells may be passively detached from the ducts and alveoli, potentially due to stresses associated with milk synthesis and secretion, alveolar expansion with milk, milk ejection, and vacuum applied to the breast during milk removal by either the baby or breast pump.70 New data support the theory that this epithelial detachment may be an active phenomenon associated with short-term changes in gene expression that result in a motile character in these cells36 (Figure 1B). De novo formation of tight junctions between the detached cells that form clusters in breast milk12 supports this notion and requires further investigation.

It has been demonstrated that epithelial cells often occur in clusters in breast milk and can be isolated and cultured.71,72 Of these cells, few are considered to be of ductal origin,12 although actual analysis of ductal cell marker expression has not yet been done to confirm this. Lactocytes are thought to be present in significant numbers in mature human milk. The majority of them originate from alveoli. However, evidence suggests that few lactocytes may also be present in areas where ducts transition to alveoli, suggesting that some lactocytes found in milk may be of ductal origin.2 Initial studies suggested a range of 11% to 99% lactocytes of the total breast milk cell population.39,73 More recently, a more conservative estimate of 10% to 28% of the total cell content has been suggested.38 It would be pertinent to confirm these estimates with examination of the numbers of cells expressing milk proteins using flow cytometry, a technique that provides high specificity and consistency. In this context, we have found a range of 32% to 86% β-casein-expressing cells in freshly expressed breast milk (n = 12) (Hassiotou, unpublished data). These differences are likely due to variations in the population and/or differences in classification due to different techniques or methodology used. Recently, it was demonstrated that in addition to luminal ductal or alveolar epithelial cells, breast milk contains myoepithelial cells from the basal epithelial layer of ducts and alveoli2,31,67,74-76 (Figure 3A).

caption.p: Breast Milk Cellular Heterogeneity and the Presence of Stem Cells with Pluripotent Traits

A. Myoepithelial cells (green: smooth muscle actin, SMA) in freshly isolated breast milk cell preparations. Red: nuclear stain (PI). Scale bar: 10 µm. B. Three distinct colony types obtained from the culture of breast milk cells: a luminal-like, a myoepithelial-like, and a mixed colony. Scale bar: 50 µm. C. Cells isolated from freshly expressed breast milk staining positive for the pluripotency markers OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG. Blue: nuclear stain (DAPI). Scale bar: 2.5 µm. D. Variation in expression of pluripotency markers between women. Expression was quantified by Flow Activated Cell Sorting (FACS), and the graph shows the standardized difference in Mean Fluorescence Intensity between the test and the control. B-D are adapted from Hassiotou et al.35

sec.p: In culture, breast milk epithelial populations actively divide at a rate depending on the sample and growth conditions, forming at least 3 distinct types of colonies: closed, open, and mixed colonies77 (Figure 3B). Breast milk-derived epithelial colonies contain 1 or more of the main breast epithelial types, including luminal cells (alveolar, CK18+, and ductal, CK19+) and myoepithelial cells (CK14+/SMA+). They also contain more than 1 of the differentiation stages of these cell types.35

The majority of previous studies examined the different epithelial subpopulations of breast milk morphologically.78 Although this has contributed to our understanding of the ultrastructure of these cells, it is not sufficient for delineation of the various differentiation stages represented in breast milk. Flow cytometry and molecular analyses are now aiding characterization of the different breast milk cell types, their origin, and their potential functions. It is now suggested that breast milk contains cells across a developmental hierarchy.2,35 These cells include early-stage stem cells, various progenitor cells, and more differentiated myoepithelial and milk-secretory cells, representing the mammary developmental continuum.2,35

sec.title: Breast Milk Stem Cells
sec.p: The presence of stem cells in breast milk (hBSCs) was suggested by early reports that showed the ability of breast milk cell preparations to expand in culture and form different colony types, which could be maintained through multiple passages.12,71-73,77 More recently, Cregan and colleagues described expression of the stem cell markers CK5 and nestin within colonies generated from the culture of breast milk cells.31 Subsequently, expression of the stem/progenitor cell markers p63 and CD49f was shown in breast milk cells, which were able to self-renew in spheroid culture and differentiate into CK18+ luminal cells and CK14+ myoepithelial cells.33,34 The field was revolutionized by the recent discovery of expression of pluripotency markers by hBSC subpopulations,2,35 including OCT4, SOX2, and NANOG (Figure 3C), which comprise the core transcription factor (TF) circuitry controlling the undifferentiated state and pluripotential of human embryonic stem cells (hESCs).79 Expression levels of these TFs and other stem cell and differentiation genes by breast milk cells vary widely both between and within women (Figure 3D), with ongoing studies focusing on elucidating factors that influence this variability. Elegant 3D assays confirmed the ability of hBSCs to self-renew in a manner that retains expression of these pluripotency genes.35 In vitro differentiation assays demonstrated the ability of hBSCs to differentiate not only into cells of the mammary lineage that synthesize and secrete milk proteins but also into cells of other lineages in both a spontaneous and directed fashion.35 These included cells with properties of neurons, cardiomyocytes, osteoblasts, chondrocytes, adipocytes, hepatocytes, and pancreatic beta cells.35 That study provided the first evidence that hBSC subpopulations are capable of differentiating into cells from all 3 germ layers, suggesting that they are pluripotent. This was reinforced by direct in vitro comparison of hBSCs with hESCs,35 which are known to be pluripotent.79 However, in contrast to hESCs, hBSCs did not form tumors when injected subcutaneously in severe combined immunodeficient (SCID) mice in the teratoma assay,35 suggesting (a) a fundamental difference between pluripotent cells in the embryo and in the adult, which has been previously supported by studies in adult pluripotent stem cells isolated from the bone marrow,80,81 and (b) that the teratoma assay may not be appropriate to assess pluripotency of adult non-tumorigenic cells.35,82

Yet, hBSCs may be capable of integrating in vivo and differentiating within tissues, which remains to be investigated. This may open new avenues for delineating the role of hBSCs for the breastfed infant and their potential use in stem cell therapeutics and regenerative medicine.83 Importantly, the ability of hBSCs to differentiate into cells similar to functional pancreatic beta islets, synthesizing insulin, and functional hepatocytes, synthesizing albumin,35 holds great promise for the development of personalized treatments for diabetes and liver diseases, which should be further explored. In this connection, banking of hBSCs may allow their retrospective therapeutic usage, similar to cord blood stem cell banking. Umbilical cord blood is not plentiful, and its content in stem cells is limited. Future research can examine the suitability of and develop methods for appropriate storage and banking of hBSCs.

hBSCs expressing pluripotency markers originate at least in part from the lactating epithelium, both the luminal and myoepithelial layer.35 These cells are scarce in the resting breast.35 This suggests that hormonal changes occurring during pregnancy/lactation stimulate upregulation of pluripotency genes in MaSCs, which undergo a controlled program of proliferation and differentiation, facilitating the remodeling of the breast into a milk-secretory organ. This controlled program of MaSC expansion may be regulated by epigenetic mechanisms influencing ESC TFs and their downstream targets in various stages of mammary development.

Some of the stem or progenitor cells present in breast milk may be mobilized by other organs and end up in the breast through the systemic circulation. In agreement with this hypothesis, a small population of cells expressing hematopoietic stem cell markers (CD34, CD133) has been previously reported in breast milk.67,74-76 Further research will determine whether this is a true hematopoietic stem cell population and whether it contributes to the ESC-like hBSC population expressing pluripotency markers that has been previously described.35 Importantly, the ESC-like hBSC population expressing pluripotency genes may be a heterogeneous population of stem and progenitor cells including more than 1 differentiation stage, as is suggested by the differing subcellular marker localization and levels of expression within this population.2,35 Therefore, it can be concluded based on current evidence that a wide spectrum of developmental stages and functionalities is represented in breast milk, which reflects the cellular hierarchy and developmental stage of the lactating breast. This creates new opportunities for using breast milk as a source of cells to study the normal biology of the breast and its pathologies.

In addition to the epithelium, fewer single positive cells for ESC markers can be found in the stroma of the lactating breast35 (Figure 4A). This, together with the ability of the ESC-marker+ hBSCs to differentiate into stromal cells in the right microenvironment, raises the question: can there be a single precursor for the epithelial and the stromal mammary tissue? If this is the case, this single precursor may be found both in the stroma and in the epithelium or it may be primarily localized in the basal epithelial layer. To effect stromal remodeling, this would involve cell migration from the epithelial into the stromal layer via the basement membrane. Of note, the majority of cells in the stroma positive for pluripotency markers are localized close to the epithelium (Hassiotou, unpublished data). This migratory and differentiation process could involve Epithelial-to-Mesenchymal Transition (EMT). Indeed, there is evidence of EMT in the murine lactating mammary gland,84 and we confirmed this in humans (Figure 4B). EMT in the context of embryonic development and breast cancer is not merely expression of mesenchymal genes but also involves secretion of matrix metalloproteinases, which disrupt the basement membrane enabling the EMT-cell to invade the underlying stroma.84 It is therefore possible that in the lactating gland under physiological EMT, a stem cell subpopulation from the basal epithelial compartment invades the stroma and is responsible for its expansion. This is supported by the reconstruction of a fully functional mammary gland by a single cell85 and merits further study.

caption.p: Unique Properties of the Mammary Epithelium and Stroma during Lactation in Women

A. OCT4+ cells in the stroma as well as in the epithelium in the lactating breast. White arrows point to some examples of positive cells in the mammary stroma. Scale bar: 20 µm. Adapted from Hassiotou et al.35 B. Evidence for Epithelial-to-Mesenchymal Transition (EMT) in the alveoli and ducts of the human lactating breast. Red: vimentin. Blue: nuclear stain (DAPI). Scale bar: 5 µm.

sec.p: In addition to EMT markers, breast milk has been suggested to contain cells with a mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) phenotype,76,86 expressing markers such as CD90, CD105, CD73, and others characteristic of MSCs.87 Given the apparent overlap of mesenchymal and epithelial markers in breast milk,67,74 it can be postulated that the mesenchymal markers are indicative of EMT and not of MSCs, particularly since they are found to be expressed in the lactating mammary epithelium (Figure 4B). Thus, the lactating epithelium may manifest unique properties reflected in the cells entering and isolated from breast milk. Future research should address these questions and examine breast milk cell subpopulations using mesenchymal and epithelial markers in combination, together with staining of lactating breast tissue, in order to illuminate the origin and properties of these cells.

sec.title: Roles of Breast Milk Stem Cells for the Breastfed Infant
sec.p: The majority of breast milk cells are viable in freshly expressed breast milk, with cell viabilities, as obtained from Trypan Blue exclusion using a hemocytometer, ranging from 70% to 100% (n = 234; > 90% for n = 202) (Hassiotou, unpublished data). Considering the known variation in breast milk cell content of 10 000 to 13 000 000 cells/mL36 and the normal daily milk consumption by infants of 470 to 1350 mL,10 it can be estimated that 5 × 106 to 17 × 109 milk cells are ingested by breastfed infants every day, of which 4 × 106 to 17 × 109 are viable. It is still not clear how many of these cells are stem cells, how many are capable of displaying pluripotential in vivo, and how their numbers and properties may change during lactation. Considering breast milk cells with the pluripotency phenotype OCT4+/SOX2+/NANOG+, it can be inferred from current data that these cells appear in breast milk in numbers of < 1% to 30% or more of total breast milk cells (Hassiotou, unpublished data).

Thus, infants ingest thousands to millions of viable hBSCs with every breastfeed, raising the question of the potential role of these cells in the infant. Research in animal models, including a primate model, has demonstrated that milk leukocytes diapedese through the intestinal mucosa to enter the systemic circulation, through which they are transferred to various organs and contribute to the protection and immune development of the young.57,58,60,61 Similarly, hBSCs may also enter the blood circulation to be transported to distant organs.35 This may result in microchimerism, whereby maternal stem cells are engrafted in infant organs, contributing to tissue homeostasis, repair, and/or regeneration. This phenomenon of stem cell exchange has been observed before in the mother-offspring dyad in a reciprocal way in utero.88 We suggest that this process may continue postnatally via breastfeeding. The breastfed infant’s immune system appears to be uniquely tolerized to maternal antigens and cells exposed to via breast milk and also potentially provides a favorable environment for their utilization. This is evident in the better tolerance and success rates of maternal transplants by individuals who have been breastfed as infants.89,90 Future research should focus on illuminating the role of breast milk stem cells for the breastfed infant, which may lead to improvement of public policy for early infant nutrition, given the absence of human cells in artificial milk.

In addition to the cells, studies could also consider cellular constituents, such as messenger RNAs (mRNAs) and microRNAs, which are present in breast milk and are transported to the breastfed infant, often embedded in microvesicles.91-93 Breast milk mRNAs may enter the infant’s cells and get translated in this new environment to provide functional attributes to the infant.91 At the same time, microRNAs from food sources have been shown to regulate gene expression after consumption in adults,94 rendering it likely that breast milk microRNAs may regulate gene expression in the infant. Thus, breast milk, via its cells and nucleic acids, may transfer genetic signals to the infant. Of interest, the tolerance of the natural consumption of hBSCs and their constituents, such as RNAs, by breastfed infants raises the possibility of natural breast milk cell-based therapies for neonatal genetic diseases.

sec.title: Breast Milk Cells as a Tool to Understand the Biology and Pathology of the Breast
sec.p: Human breast tissue, particularly during lactation, is scarce. Breast milk can be used as a non-invasive and plentiful source of cells from the lactating breast to study the normal biology of this organ and its pathologies. Reflecting the epithelium of the lactating breast and its developmental hierarchy, gene expression studies in breast milk cells may be used as an indicator of breast tissue differentiation and functionality during lactation and/or as an assessment of lactation potential. This may prove particularly useful in managing lactation difficulties, such as low or over supply of milk, and secretory activation, which may be delayed in mothers of preterm infants.95,96

In addition to lactation biology, breast milk cells can be used as a model to understand breast malignancy. Increasing evidence is suggesting that MaSCs are targets of malignant transformation and responsible for initiation, progression, and metastasis of breast cancer, at least for certain cancer subtypes.97-99 The scarcity of MaSCs in the resting breast has hindered understanding of their regulation. The identification of an ESC-like population in breast milk opens new avenues for examination of the regulation of the normal self-renewal of these cells, manifested in the normal lactating breast. It has been argued that disruption of this genetic network during pregnancy and lactation, failure to silence it during involution, or its aberrant upregulation in the resting breast may be at the core of breast malignancies.2,35 Interestingly, these ESC genes have been shown to be upregulated in certain breast tumors,97,100 suggesting a link between the normal hBSCs and these cancer stem-like cells. It will be important to tease apart differences in gene expression between the normal breast stem cells accessed via breast milk and their malignant counterparts, which may lead to innovative treatments for breast cancer. Thus, breast milk may prove an invaluable source of normal MaSCs for the study of molecular determinants of malignancy.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Being relevant not only as a reflection of the health and developmental status of the breast but also for their functions in the breastfed infant, breast milk cells will be a major research focus in lactation as well as stem cell biology and regenerative medicine in the future. In addition to potential hBSC use in therapeutics, areas that will leverage benefits from breast milk cells span from the immunology and health status of the breast and the infant, to lactation efficiency and performance, to the development of the breast epithelium and its malignancies, to postnatal microchimerism via breastfeeding. Breast milk cells are live when consumed by the infant during breastfeeding, suggesting that they confer modulatory and developmental benefits far beyond what is currently known. Further study of these effects may revolutionize lactation biology and breastfeeding physiology and open new avenues for improvement of the understanding of the importance of breastfeeding. As multidimensional as breast milk cell content is, further research will benefit from multidisciplinary collaborations that may view breast milk from the perspective of a complex biosystem rather than a food source.

ack.p: Many thanks are extended to all participating mothers and the Australian Breastfeeding Association for support in recruitment of participants. The authors acknowledge Ms Mary Lee and Ms Leonie Khoo (UWA) for tissue sectioning and the facilities and scientific and technical assistance of the Australian Microscopy & Microanalysis Research Facility at the Centre for Microscopy, Characterisation & Analysis, The University of Western Australia.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: This work was supported by an unrestricted research grant from Medela AG (Switzerland) to FH, DTG, and PEH, and a Women and Infants Research Foundation Scholarship to FH. Neither of these organizations had any input in writing or the decision to publish the article.
